speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Roz, I think we have just enough time for one more call.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay, we have Andy from Bremerton on line three.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Andy, I'm listening.

speaker: Andy
text: [_v.o._] Am I on?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, go ahead.

speaker: Andy
text: Can you hear me?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, you're on the air.

speaker: Andy
text: Hello?

speaker: Frasier
text: You're on.

speaker: Andy
text: Am I on?

speaker: Frasier
text: Not any more. [_cuts him off_] This is Dr. Frasier Crane on KACL, wishing you good mental health.  _Frasier and Roz disconnect and take their headsets off.  Kenny comes in with several other KACL people._

speaker: Kenny
text: Gather round everyone.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Kenny, what's all this?

speaker: Kenny
text: I'm here to officially announce this year's SeaBea nominations.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well.

speaker: Gil
text: He made us wait until your show was over.  It was interminable.

speaker: Kenny
text: First of all, KACL has been nominated for a total of nine SeaBeas.

speaker: Kenny
text: Which ties us with KPXY, the mighty Pixie, for most nominations.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, the mighty Pixie, they do very well.

speaker: Kenny
text: Now, all the nominees were chosen by a panel of experts...

speaker: Roz
text: Just give me that!

speaker: Frasier
text: Good girl, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, here's one: "Best Restaurant Critic: Gil Chesterton."

speaker: Gil
text: Oh, thank God I'm nominated!  Now I won't have to attend "The Chestertons."

speaker: Roz
text: "The Chestertons?"

speaker: Gil
text: It's an elaborate awards show my wife and the dogs put on when I'm overlooked by the SeaBeas.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I don't see our names anywhere.

speaker: Roz
text: No, nothing, we've been shut out.  I don't believe it!

speaker: Kenny
text: Well, what do I have here?

speaker: Frasier
text: There are more awards?

speaker: Kenny
text: Maybe.  I guess you'll just have to listen and find out. "Since 1962, the Seattle broadcasting community..."

speaker: Roz
text: Give me that!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh my God, Frasier!  You're getting a lifetime achievement award!

speaker: Frasier
text: What?  Are you serious?!

speaker: Roz
text: Yes, it says right here: "Since 1962..."

speaker: Frasier
text: Give me that!

speaker: Kenny
text: Hurts, doesn't it?  _Roz nods, looking a bit guilty.  FADE OUT.  Scene 2 - Frasier's Apartment Fade in.  Frasier is holding one of his pieces of African art, practicing his acceptance speech in front of Eddie._

speaker: Frasier
text: When I was a boy, my parents told me to reach for the stars. Sadly, I later learned that stars are just massive fiery balls of gas, which, were I to reach one, would vaporize me instantly.  But tonight, with the Stephen R. Schafer Lifetime Achievement Award, you tell me that I have reached you, and you, ladies and gentlemen, are my stars. [_to Eddie_] And that's where you would applaud.  _Eddie lets out a big yawn and scurries off to the bedrooms.  Martin comes from there wearing a tuxedo._

speaker: Martin
text: I gotta say, Fras, it's really somethin', you gettin' this award.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Dad, it's actually quite an honor.  You know, customarily, they give them out to much older people.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles, flowers!  How very thoughtful of you!

speaker: Niles
text: They're not from me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thank you for bringing them up.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, actually, they were just outside the door.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thank you for bending over and picking them up.

speaker: Niles
text: Well it wasn't that far, the handle...

speaker: Frasier
text: Just give them to me! _He takes the flowers and puts them on the table behind the couch. He takes the card and reads it aloud._

speaker: Frasier
text: "Congratulations, Frasier.  You must be very proud.  William Tewksbury."

speaker: Martin
text: Who's that?

speaker: Frasier
text: He's my old mentor from Harvard, Dad.  Gosh, you know, I read in the alumni newsletter that he was taking his sabbatical here at the University of Washington, I've been meaning to call him.

speaker: Martin
text: Niles, somethin' here for you.

speaker: Niles
text: For me, what for?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, this may be Frasier's night, but I just want you to know that I have two special sons.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, how considerate.

speaker: Niles
text: "World's Greatest Psychiatrist."

speaker: Martin
text: See, your brother's not the only one gettin' a prize tonight.

speaker: Niles
text: Thanks, Dad.  Oh, there's my little rose bud.  Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: Is it my imagination, or has she gained weight since breakfast?

speaker: Martin
text: Which seating?  Eight, nine, or ten?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, darling, you're undone.

speaker: Daphne
text: I know.  This dress used to fit perfectly, now I can't even get it zipped halfway up.  Those bloody cleaners must have shrunk it.

speaker: Niles
text: Let me give it a try. _He strains at the zipper, then puts his knee up to get more leverage, but can't move it._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, my.

speaker: Daphne
text: Maybe if I put a jacket on.  Would you come help me pick one out?

speaker: Niles
text: Sure, sure.  You know, you should switch dry cleaners, that's the third dress they've shrunk this week.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, what do you make of this? [_reading card_] "Congratulations, Frasier.  You must be very proud."

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I'd say he's happy for you.  Of course, I was a detective, so it comes easy to me.

speaker: Frasier
text: He doesn't say he's proud of me, he says that I should be proud of myself.  Doesn't that seem a bit odd to you?

speaker: Martin
text: No, you're splittin' hairs.

speaker: Frasier
text: You don't know Dr. Tewksbury like I do.  He wouldn't say something like this unless he meant to say something else.

speaker: Martin
text: You're gonna let this ruin the whole night for you, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, of course not, Dad.  I just think it's interesting, that's all.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Dad, I'm gonna head over to the SeaBeas a little early.  I'll see you there.

speaker: Martin
text: Why?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I thought I should... familiarize myself with the dais.

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, it's just a note.

speaker: Frasier
text: I know, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: It doesn't mean anything.

speaker: Frasier
text: I know, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Say "Hi" to Dr. Tewksbury for me.

speaker: Frasier
text: I will, Dad.  _He exits.  FADE OUT.  Scene 3 - Dr. Tewksbury's Office Fade in.  Dr. Tewksbury is at his desk, straightening up. Frasier comes in._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Tewksbury?  Frasier Crane.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Of course!  Frasier.  It's good to see you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Likewise.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: How long has it been?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, gosh, perhaps...twenty years.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: That long?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah.  Actually, I was on my way to the awards ceremony and I thought I'd drop by and thank you for the flowers.  And the card.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: You're welcome.

speaker: Frasier
text: It was very thoughtful of you.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: I was happy to do it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Particularly the card.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: I'm glad you liked it.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, let's cut the bull.  "You must be very proud." Why not "I'm proud of you"?  Why speculation rather than declaration?  We both know there are no mistakes.  There must have been some reason either conscious or subconscious that you chose these words.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Frasier, I have a confession to make.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah!

speaker: Tewksbury
text: My assistant wrote the card.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: You see, when I heard you were getting an award, I asked her to send flowers with a note of congratulations.  I'm afraid you've been over analyzing.

speaker: Frasier
text: I see.  Then again, perhaps, in that order to your assistant, you subconsciously transmitted an emotion  that you couldn't or didn't want to acknowledge.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Or perhaps your subconscious assigned new meaning to the words to reflect your self-doubt.

speaker: Frasier
text: But all art is self portraiture, and that includes the written word.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: However, we can only view art through the lens of our own psyches.

speaker: Frasier
text: Then there is no pure art.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: How would you know?

speaker: Frasier
text: God, I've missed you!

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Frasier, of course I'm proud of you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  It's so nice to know that, it really is.  Thank you.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Oh, I really wish we had more time to talk, but I'm taking my wife out to dinner tonight, I have to pick up some flowers before the shops close.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, of course.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: This time, I think I'll write the card myself.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, that's a good idea.  Gosh, it was great to see you again.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Yes.  Let's get together some evening.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'd like that.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: It's not often I get to dine with the recipient of a lifetime achievement award.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, please, it's just a trinket for a little radio show I do.  Uh, not that by "little" I mean to minimize my achievement.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: I know.

speaker: Frasier
text: I know you know.  I just want to be clear, so that you don't infer any meanings that aren't actually there.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: What might I infer?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you know, that I'm somehow dissatisfied with my work, something like that.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: You also called the award a trinket.  Can you imagine what I might have done with that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Exactly.  A lesser therapist might say that I, I didn't think much of an award that they're willing to give to the likes of me.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: I suppose if one were looking hard enough, one could even say your coming down here was a desperate quest for approval.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that one's a little out there.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Frasier, you don't have to worry.  I'm not inferring anything.  Enjoy yourself this evening.

speaker: Frasier
text: I will.  Because tonight is my night.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: So long, Professor.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Goodbye. _Frasier leaves.  Dr. Tewksbury gets his things together and shakes his head reflectively._

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Oh, Frasier...  _He goes out and locks the door behind him.  Turning around, he sees Frasier sitting on the steps, his head in his hand._

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: What the hell is wrong with me?  _Tewksbury pats him on the back and urges him towards the office.  End of Act 1  Act 2  Scene 1 - Dr. Tewksbury's Office Fade in.  Frasier is looking out the window, Dr. Tewksbury is on the phone._

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Yes, dear, I know we have reservations but one of my former students is having a minor crisis.  I'll be there in half an hour.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shouting out the window_] WHAT DOES IT ALL MEAN?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Make it an hour. _FADE OUT  Scene 2 - The SeaBea Awards Fade in.  Martin, Niles and Daphne are sitting at their table. Roz comes up._

speaker: Roz
text: Hello everybody.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Roz.  Whoa!  You look great, Roz!

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, that's a beautiful dress.

speaker: Roz
text: Thank you.  And after two weeks of eating delicious fat-burning cabbage soup, it finally fits.

speaker: Daphne
text: Niles made me cabbage with me ossu buco last night.  If I knew it burned fat, I would have had a fourth helping.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, we do have leftovers.

speaker: Daphne
text: No we don't.

speaker: Roz
text: [_aside to Martin_] I haven't seen Daphne in a while.  Is it my imagination...?

speaker: Martin
text: No.  Six squares a day.

speaker: Roz
text: That's not like her.  Maybe she's depressed.  That's when I eat.  Did you say anything to her?

speaker: Martin
text: Nope.  Timing's very delicate in somethin' like this, Roz. I figured I'd wait until after she's too big to catch me but before she needs the motorized scooter. _She laughs.  He holds her chair for her.  They sit and Kenny comes over._

speaker: Kenny
text: Hey, has anyone seen Frasier?

speaker: Martin
text: No, not yet.  What's the matter, you look pale.

speaker: Kenny
text: Well, I hate public speaking, and they roped me into giving Frasier's introduction and I want to make sure it's okay.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, why don't you run it by Niles?  He's a psychiatrist too. And he's just as smart and successful as Frasier.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad...

speaker: Martin
text: It's true, you are. [_to Kenny_] He is.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Gil.  So, where is that elusive wife of yours?

speaker: Gil
text: If you must know, Deb's on maneuvers with her reserve unit.

speaker: Emcee
text: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to this year's Seattle Broadcasting Awards.  Let's get right to our first category: outstanding restaurant critic.  And the nominees are: Merrill George for "Cafe Chat", Sheldon Hastings for "Here's Looking at Food" and Gil Chesterton for "Restaurant Beat."  And... we have a tie!

speaker: Gil
text: They expect me to share?  What is this, dim sum?

speaker: Emcee
text: And the SeaBeas go to Merrill George and Sheldon Hastings.

speaker: Gil
text: No, this can't be happening.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, come on, Gil, isn't it enough just to be nominated?

speaker: Gil
text: You tell me, Miss Three-Time-Loser!   **HE WORE HIS FIRST SMOKING JACKET AT 12**  _Scene 3 - Dr. Tewksbury's Office Fade in.  Frasier is talking to Tewksbury._

speaker: Frasier
text: I know I should be happy but I feel so dissatisfied.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Well, Frasier, it's no accident that you're going through this on the day that you receive your lifetime achievement award.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, duh. [_then_] I'm sorry, I'm just acting out.  Please, please.  Continue, please.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: As you know, men in our society commonly define themselves by their careers.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I'll cop to that.  In fact, there's nothing I'm more proud of than my career.  It's because I love to help people, I always have.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: All right, refresh my memory.  Wasn't it your mother who first sparked your interest in psychiatry?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, it was.  I remember the exact day.  I was eight.  I'd come home crying because one of the older boys had thrown my copy of "The Fountainhead" under a bus.  My mother explained to me it wasn't because he didn't like the way I walked or because I wore an ascot to school, it was because he didn't like himself.  And at that very moment, I became a student of human behavior.  It was as if someone had given me an instruction manual explaining why people acted the way they did.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Not to mention a way to distance yourself from painful emotions.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, totally.  I took a lot of grief for that ascot.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: So, you were drawn to psychiatry not because you like to help people, but because you feared them.

speaker: Frasier
text: I feared them?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Psychiatry gives you objectivity.  Objectivity gives you emotional distance.  Distance makes you feel safe.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, granted.  But what does that got to do with me?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: How's your practice?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't have a practice, I have a radio show.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Distance.  Any children?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I have a wonderful son with whom I'm very close.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: You live with him?

speaker: Frasier
text: He lives in Boston.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Distance.  With your wife.

speaker: Frasier
text: My ex-wife - yes, I know, distance.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Wasn't she a psychiatrist?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, she was.  She happens to be a damn good one, too.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Well, that's a handy choice for someone who'd rather share ideas than emotions.

speaker: Frasier
text: Have you ever met Lilith?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: No.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, she happens to be a very warm and loving woman!

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Have you had any other meaningful relationships since then?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as a matter of fact... what is your point?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: My point is that at the age of eight - at EIGHT - you began to use psychiatry as a way to deal with a world that scared you to death.  And this lifetime achievement award has made you realize that your career is finite and once it's gone, all you'll have left is that frightened eight-year-old boy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... would you like to hear my theory?  You have no idea what you're talking about.  I am not an eight-year-old.

speaker: Frasier
text: And you know something else?  You're not my mentor any more!  _He storms out.  FADE OUT.  Scene 4 - The SeaBea Awards Fade in.  The gang are enjoying dinner at their table._

speaker: Daphne
text: Roz, you going to eat your quiche?

speaker: Roz
text: Are you kidding?  This would be like pulling the ripcord on my thighs.  It's nothing but cheese and butter and pastry...

speaker: Daphne
text: And bacon!  You sure you don't mind?

speaker: Niles
text: I have good news.  I just spoke to Frasier, he's on his way.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, thank goodness.   Not that I'm not having a good time with you, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, I know what you're doing.  You don't have to overcompensate. I'm not some green-eyed monster burning with envy for Frasier.

speaker: Martin
text: All right.  But if you were, I bet you'd be a great one.

speaker: Roz
text: Daphne?  I haven't seen you in a while.  How've you been, are you okay?

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm better than okay.  I'm in love with a man who loves me. He showers me with attention.  Every morning I wake up wondering what treasures this day will bring.  It really is the happiest time of my life.  And how are you?

speaker: Roz
text: [_choked_] Good. [_flat_] Really good. [_to Kenny_] Could you pass me Frasier's quiche? _Kenny passes it over.  Roz picks it up with her hand and takes a big bite._

speaker: Roz
text: And the butter?  _He passes it over.  FADE OUT.  Scene 5 - Dr. Tewksbury's Office Fade in.  Dr. Tewksbury is preparing to leave again.  Frasier bursts in._

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, professor.  You know, I hate to be the one to break it to you, but I'm afraid you've lost your touch. Where's your DSM?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Uh, there. _He points to a large reference book that Frasier picks up and begins searching through._

speaker: Frasier
text: "Emotionally stunted eight-year-old," my eye! [_finds the reference_] Ah, here's what I'm going through: "Phase-of-life issue: a problem associated with a particular developmental phase or other life circumstance."

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Please.  A mid-life crisis?

speaker: Frasier
text: Obvious, really.  You know, I'm surprised it didn't occur to me sooner.  If someone had called into my show with this problem, I'd have diagnosed it inside a minute.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: And then what would you have done?

speaker: Frasier
text: That depends on the caller.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: All right.  The caller... is you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: On line one, we have Frasier Crane from Seattle.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Dr. Crane.  I love your show, I'm a big fan. [_laughs, then_] I won't bore you with all the details of my life... because you know them.  Suffice to say, I'm a successful psychiatrist.  My problem is that, in spite of the life I've built, I feel... empty.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, emptiness.  The eternal void.  If I'm not mistaken, it was John Keats who once wrote...

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Stalling.  Deal with the feelings.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, fair enough.  Perhaps caller, if we reframe the issue...

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Redefining the problem.  Deal with the feelings.

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh... let's run down Beck's Depression Inventory...

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Re-diagnosing.  You know what the problem is: the caller feels empty.  Go on.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.  Last month in the _New England Journal_...

speaker: Tewksbury
text: He's already read it.

speaker: Frasier
text: How do you know?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: The caller is Frasier Crane.  If you did, he did.

speaker: Frasier
text: I can suggest certain visualization techniques...

speaker: Tewksbury
text: He knows them already.

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, if he knows all this, then why is he calling?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: He told you: because he's empty.  Keep going.

speaker: Frasier
text: Sometimes it helps to write yourself a letter...

speaker: Tewksbury
text: He's already got himself on the phone.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know what he wants!

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Then why do you keep trying to bury him in psychiatric exercises?

speaker: Frasier
text: Because that's all I have!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, caller, I can't help you. _FADE OUT  Scene 6 - The SeaBea Awards Fade in.  Kenny hurries over to the table again._

speaker: Kenny
text: Frasier's up next.  He's not here yet, what the hell am I gonna do?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, he'll be here in a minute.  Just go up there and stall.

speaker: Kenny
text: [_panicked_] Stall?  Stall?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, like that.

speaker: Emcee
text: Ladies and gentleman, our next presenter, KACL General Manager, Kenny Daily.

speaker: Kenny
text: I think I'm gonna be sick.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, fine, relax.  I'll go up there for you.

speaker: Martin
text: No, Niles, let me do it.  This night's been hard enough on you already.

speaker: Roz
text: You are such a weenie.

speaker: Kenny
text: [_suddenly much calmer_] Yeah.  Weenie like a fox.

speaker: Martin
text: Actually, ladies and gentlemen, I'm Martin Crane.  Kenny very kindly let me do the honors.  You see, I'm Frasier's dad.

speaker: Martin
text: No, no.  More than that, I'm the father of two special guys. So if it's okay with you, I'd like you to give a big SeaBea welcome to my other son, Niles.  C'mon, Niles, stand up, let 'em see you.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, here's Frasier.

speaker: Martin
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I give you the winner of the Stephen R. Shafer Lifetime Achievement Award, my son, Frasier Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah.  Thank you for honoring my life.  Just wish I knew what to do with the rest of it. _The guests laugh.  Frasier stands for a moment, then walks off. Martin and Kenny look surprised._

speaker: Roz
text: What the hell was that?
